issues.title: Ed25519 compatibility
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Beyond ristretto255, we should describe how to instantiate FROST with the [edwards25519 curve from RFC 8032](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8032#section-5.1). We might include the EdDSA verification procedure, too, listed below (bugs are my own):

~~~
EdDSA_verify(msg, sig, PK)

Inputs:
- msg, message signed, an octet string
- sig, message signature, a tuple of scalars (z, c)
- PK, EdDSA public key

Outputs: 1 if the signature is valid, and 0 otherwise

def EdDSA_verify(msg, sig, PK):
  (z, c) = SIG
  R' = (z * P) + (PK * c^-1)
  c' = Hash(m, R')
  if c == c':
    return 1
  return 0
~~~

issues.title: Drop SUM/PROD notation in favor of subroutines
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
We use SUM/PROD for convenience, but I find it to be somewhat unreadable in text form. For example, this:

~~~
f_zero = SUM(points[0], points[t]){point}: point[1] * derive_lagrange_coefficient(point[0], L)
~~~

Could be written as:

~~~
f_zero = F(0)
for point in points:
   f_zero = f_zero + (point[1] * derive_lagrange_coefficient(point[0], L))
~~~

This is certainly subjective, but I find the latter easier to read in text form. (It would be lovely if we could throw \sum and \prod in specs!)

issues.title: Length of message to be signed should be larger
issues.author: chelseakomlo

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
Upon revisiting this, I think we ought to remove the practical limit entirely and let applications define it. We should define the theoretical limit based on the underlying cryptographic hash function, but how applications choose to wrap up messages between coordinator and signers should be left to those applications, I think.

Basically, I think I'm now advocating for removing `SigningPackage` and the like as _requirements_. A shared wire format isn't necessary for interoperability here.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: I agree that the message length should be unbounded but I'm uncertain about removing the `SigningPackage` wire format altogether. Do you mind saying why this is a preferable option than just allowing the message length to be variable-sized in this data structure?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> Do you mind saying why this is a preferable option than just allowing the message length to be variable-sized in this data structure?

Sure: it will surely vary by use case and application embedding, so a one-size-fits-all structure isn't necessary for interop. Thus, I think we ought to just remove it.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Ok. We can keep `SigningPackage` as an example, but remove the requirement that implementations enforce this structure? I can do this change.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I would hold off until we have a larger discussion about it. I think this relates to the interface that this specification should expose, which is something I raised in #62.

comments.author: chris-wood

issues.title: Single-party signature generation and verification, accounting for cofactors
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
The [current verification](https://cfrg.github.io/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost.html#name-schnorr-signature-operation) routine diverges from RFC8032. In particular, it does this:

~~~
def schnorr_signature_verify(msg, sig = (R, z), PK):
    msg_hash = H3(msg)
    comm_enc = G.SerializeElement(R)
    pk_enc = G.SerializeElement(PK)
    challenge_input = group_comm_enc || group_public_key_enc || msg_hash
    c = H2(challenge_input)

    l = ScalarBaseMult(z)
    r = R + (c * PK)
    if l == r:
      return 1
    return 0
~~~

When it should do something like this (partially modified from [ed25519-zebra's ZIP15-based verification check](https://github.com/ZcashFoundation/ed25519-zebra/blob/main/src/verification_key.rs)):

~~~
def schnorr_signature_verify(msg, sig = (R, z), PK):
    msg_hash = H3(msg)
    comm_enc = G.SerializeElement(R)
    pk_enc = G.SerializeElement(PK)
    challenge_input = group_comm_enc || group_public_key_enc || msg_hash
    c = H2(challenge_input)

    # Check that [8][Z]B = [8]R + [8][c]PK:
    # <=> 0 == [8](R - ([z]B - [c]PK))
    # <=> 0 == [8](R - R'), where R' = [z]B - [c]PK
    
    Z = ScalarBaseMult(z)
    Rp = c * PK
    D = 8 * (R - Rp)
    return D == Identity()
~~~

This is specific to RFC8032 and Ed25519, where the cofactor of the curve is 8, so we probably need to write this in terms of a more general cofactor `h`. This probably relates to #12, so cc @dconnolly for a sanity check. =)

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Yes the 8 is because the Edwards curve has that cofactor. In the p256 and Ristretto cases, that h = 1. One way to handle this is to make the h explicit in our formulas and explicit in the ciphersuites, so h = 1, or h = 8, or whatever.

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Relatedly : https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/issues/12

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
```
def schnorr_signature_verify(msg, sig = (R, z), PK):
    comm_enc = G.SerializeElement(R)
    pk_enc = G.SerializeElement(PK)
    challenge_input = comm_enc || pk_enc || msg
    c = H2(challenge_input)

    Z = ScalarBaseMult(z)
    Rp = c * PK
    check = h * (Z - Rp - R)
    return check == G.Identity()
 ```

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body:
Notes: 
- Right now we don't have verification algorithms defined externally for P-256 and Ristretto (either for plain Schnorr or EdDSA) 
- We should define verification algorithms for these two, but others we should reference existing standards.

issues.title: Add secp256k1 ciphersuite and test vectors
issues.author: chris-wood

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Also, maybe we need to add ciphersuites for other curves that are used for Schnorr signatures? I _think_ this would include, e.g., secp256k1?

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> Also, maybe we need to add ciphersuites for other curves that are used for Schnorr signatures? I _think_ this would include, e.g., secp256k1?

I had vague plans to implement this anyway for our FROST impls but wasn't sure if we had interest in standardizing it. I was under the impression that secp256k1 is usually used in ECDSA, and that standardizing a Schnorr signature using it would be going against the grain (imo in a good direction, but). Are there other Schnorr systems using it out there?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> Are there other Schnorr systems using it out there?

I dunno! That's the question, I guess. We should make sure we show how to implement FROST for all curves that folks care about.

issues.title: Signature encoding
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: The draft doesn't take an opinionated stance on how to encode signatures -- it currently just spits out the commitment and response pair `(R, z)`. On the contrary, RFC8032 signatures are represented as the concatenation of `R` and `z`, both serialized. It seems like the RFC8032 suite ought to produce signatures in this format. But what about other ciphersuites?

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: I lean towards this, we have Signature types that are just the bytes of those elements and can easily be serialized to a concatenation

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: To clarify, by "this" you mean what's currently in the draft?

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
per meeting: 

` Serialize: Ciphersuite.SerializeElement(R) || Ciphersuite.SerializeScalar(z)
`

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: Just in case, is there any danger to not checking for valid points when verifying? I think not because it's verification and everything is public but I was working on this  recently and was curious

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Good question. I don't think so? It seems harmless to add a check, just to be safe, but... here be dragons.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body:
It looks like RFC8032 checks for valid points when verifying, so we should probably as well in the places where we define single-party verification. 

https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8032#section-3.4

Good catch @dconnolly !

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @chelseakomlo will you have time to prepare a PR for this, or would you like me to do it?

issues.title: Simplify commitment list structure
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: The data structure we use for the group commitment list is a bit _too_ precise. For example, implementations could choose to do store this in some other way, subject to the same sorted constraint. We should change this so that the data structure contents are clear, but the implementation-specific details are not forced upon users. One way to do that might be to say that the commitment list is a sorted list of objects, where each object has named fields for things like the "index," "hiding_nonce_commitment," and "binding_nonce_commitment."

issues.title: secret_share_shard should allow both the input secret and coefficients to be zero
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
Currently, `secret_share_shard` requires that coefficients be non-zero, as they are sampled using `RandomScalar`. Further, `DeserializeElement` requires non-identity elements. However, both the secret `s` in `secret_share_shard` should be allowed to be zero, as well as each additional coefficient that is sampled at random. This is to ensure the largest possible search space for an adversary.

https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/blob/master/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost.md#shamir-secret-sharing-dep-shamir

issues.title: Highlight that single-round FROST is out of scope for the draft
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
The draft is clearly two-round, but we do not mention that FROST has a single-round variant. We should add 1-2 sentences saying what the single-round variant is, and that it is out of scope for this document. 

https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/blob/master/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost.md#two-round-frost-frost-spec

issues.title: Inconsistent notation for group public key
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: In the section on Two-Round FROST, we discuss the group's public key `PK`, but in `trusted_dealer_keygen` we use the notation `public_key`. We should also specify in the Two-Round FROST section that `PK` is an output from the key generation protocol, since participants cannot derive it directly themselves.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Closed by #120

issues.title: Group info additionally requires each signer's individual public key
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body:
Right now, we describe the coordinator and each participant as having the same `group info`. However, in order for the coordinator to perform `verify_signature_share`, the coordinator additionally requires each participant's public key. 

We can have those values be within `group_info`, to make notation easy, and to not exclude the setting where a coordinator is not used. 

We also need `trusted_dealer_keygen` to output these individual public keys, or to derive a function so that the coordinator and/or participants can derive these values themselves (it is possible to do so using only the VSS commitment).

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Closed by #121

Unrelated to this PR, but this sentence in general is even a bit broad - deriving nonces deterministically is insecure for FROST, but not necessarily for any multi-party signature scheme.

_Originally posted by @chelseakomlo in https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/pull/116#discussion_r826276585_

issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body:
So that function is deterministic, parameterized by randomness

This is out of feedback from Ian Goldberg and nicely allows different means of generating nonces (like H(random || secret_share || "contextString") per recommendation by @FiloSottile as a lesson learned from ECDSA implementations

issues.title: `trusted_dealer_keygen` should also return the PK, group public verification key
issues.author: dconnolly

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: This value is the first element in the VSS commitment- do you think having it also output as a separate variable would be clearer?

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> This value is the first element in the VSS commitment- do you think having it also output as a separate variable would be clearer?

As the function is currently written, it produces PK and then never returns it, strictly from the secret_key, with no obvious relation to the VSS commitment / coefficients; either we should remove that line, and/or explictly say that vss_commitment[0] is the PK/group verifying key

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> 

I would explicitly return it but as:

```
Outputs:
  - signer_private_keys
  - group public key
  - vss_commitment

...

    return signer_private_keys, vss_commitment[0], vss_commitment
```

Or something like that. Internally, group_public_key == vss_commitment[0], but we should make it easy to just spit it out and not require meddling in the guts of the vss commitment 'type'

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @dconnolly can you still address this issue? If not, let's just close it out.

issues.title: Nice to have: deterministic secret_share_shard
issues.author: chelseakomlo
issues.body: This is a nice to have and not a blocker, but `secret_share_shard` in the appendix could be made deterministic, to allow for ease of testing.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: +1 -- every function that generates randomness internally should probably be retrofitted to take randomness as an explicit parameter so we can produce test vectors as needed.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
Could we have the vectors defined as using a stream cipher per-signer to generate random bytes?

> random_bytes(n): Outputs n bytes, sampled uniformly at random using a cryptographically secure pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG).

> This section contains test vectors for all ciphersuites listed in {{ciphersuites}}. All Element and Scalar values are represented in serialized form and encoded in hexadecimal strings. Signatures are represented as the concatenation of their constituent parts. The input message to be signed is also encoded as a hexadecimal string.
> 
> random_bytes is defined as the output of the Chacha20 stream cipher, instantiated per signer, with a seed of H("vectors" || encode_uint16(signer)).

This means we don't have to take in randomness in each of the spec's functions and would minimize testing against the vectors to just the signatures they end up producing.

In the spec, we say "If validation fails, the Coordinator MUST abort the protocol."

We should add more reasoning as to why this is a MUST. See https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cfrg/qkz1DlchicPs6z64xtT7lgxkVqI/

issues.title: Sage and draft conflict for Ed25519 hash function definitions
issues.author: kayabaNerve
issues.body:
Sage implements wide reduction: https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/blob/6590e8e30455bfa485733d77bcdd0166825bc4d7/poc/hash.sage#L37-L51

The draft specifies just the lower 32 bytes are supposed to be reduced, not the full hash: https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/blob/6590e8e30455bfa485733d77bcdd0166825bc4d7/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost.md?plain=1#L875-L885

While I personally prefer wide reduction, I can't comment on which should be used in an IETF draft. It should be noted the provided vectors are incompatible with the spec as-is though (which I found when working on a implementation attempting to be compliant).

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
So I've been reading through the meta on this topic. Between:

- https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8032#section-5.1.6 Step 4 saying to interpret the 64-octet digest as an integer.
- "Further, this draft specifies signatures that are compatible with RFC8032."
- Emails from the archived list
- Recommendation for usage of this ciphersuite for RFC8032
- Python 8032 implementation interpreting H(m) as little-endian, not just the lower 32 bytes
- Sage...

It seems H2 is required to be as such. Regarding H1 and H4, technically those are flexible, yet I don't see why those wouldn't follow suit. The only argument I've seen against wide reduction is it not being implemented, with other constructions being simpler to workaround. Since the necessary modification to H2 will require implementations support wide reduction, modifying H1 and H4 should be solely beneficial (though potentially not in any notable way due to Ed25519's naturally low scalar modulus, which I'm unfortunately not skilled enough to comment on further).

I don't want to be too proactive, and rush forward a PR for an issue I created on a group discussion for a formal specification and reference, yet given the above, I do believe it'd be helpful to offer a PR. If I am rushing into things, please just tell me, and I'm happy to bow out while this is resolved.

comments.author: conradoplg
comments.body: Not using a wide reduction also introduces a noticeable bias in the output, doesn't it? (Not sure what are the implications...)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @kayabaNerve can we close this now that #205 landed?

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body: I don't see why not. I just didn't dare close it on my own in case the policy was wait until a release was issued with the bug fix :p

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: The policy is basically "close once the fix lands in `main` (or `master`)" =) Thanks!

issues.title: Specify signature `verify()` subroutine (or point to one) for each ciphersuite isntead
issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body:
Explicitly point to RFC-8032 verification for Ed25519, for those that don't have their own verification defined elsewhere, we inline it.

We can explicitly _recommend_, even if we cannot _enforce_, that the Ed25519 verification use the cofactor formula, and list the reasons like security, consensus verification, and batch verification consistency with singleton verification, as motivations why.

issues.title: Use per-signer rhos instead of per-group rho
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: FROST1 here we come!

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
Is there an explanation for this available? I thought this was dropped as unnecessary, and would like to personally note this would be unappreciated from an implementation standpoint.

To elaborate on the implementation considerations, the original definition from the paper has a conflict with continuous transcripts  in that they force a divergence in challenge generation. It'd require cloning multiple hash contexts before proceeding with one (or none). Ideally, transcripts would be linear machines which fully acknowledge all messages/challenges. This prevents duplicate messages from generating the same transcript. While yes, the message in this case is a unique ID, the interoperability of FROST in larger protocols declines when it can't follow this best practice.

While there would be per-signer rho constructions which are compatible with such ideals, i.e. ones which append the `l` in question (instead of setting), hash commitments and message before re-hashing with the per-signer index, or an exponential rho per-signer (removing hashing entirely, post the initial), I don't dare suggest they're in-scope for consideration under this IETF draft (beyond `H(H({(i, D, E)}, m), l)`, which is decently minimal yet still suboptimal). I do question why per-signer rhos are being reconsidered though.

Regardless, if this satisfies security concerns, I'll bow out accordingly. I just wanted to try to understand what's going on.

And sorry for the ELI5 on transcript theory to someone who obviously doesn't need it :p Just wanted to lay out my thoughts as a whole on the matter. Also demonstrates my practical understanding here, yet always eager to pick up a bit more formal knowledge as I can :)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: The motivation for this change is due to [this paper](https://eprint.iacr.org/2022/833.pdf). Handwaving over details, the optimized version we have in the draft now allows an attacker to manipulate the signing protocol such that the signers that _started_ the signing process in round 1 are not the same signers that _finished_ the process and produced the signature. One might argue that this isn't a problem in practice because the threshold requirement was not violated (`t` signers contributed, just not the `t` signers you wanted). However, this malleability is concerning, so we're going to revert the optimization for now and then solicit more feedback on this tradeoff.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Thanks @kayabaNerve for that context. Indeed, it would be helpful to have feedback on whether performance/linearity is the most important factor here, or if ensuring the signing set that was chosen is in fact the same signing set that produced a signature. Figure 12 in 2022/833 demonstrates the malleability attack that @chris-wood alluded to for the optimized FROST variant (FROST2), which the original FROST (FROST1) protects against.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
Got it. I'm happy to agree with security improvements (including malleability, which is something I personally despise). I'll try to read through the paper in a bit. Thanks for linking it :D

Regarding actual implementation, `H(B, m, l)` remains simplest, yet `H(B, m, l_0, l_1...)` offers the appreciated linearity. `H(H(B, m), l)`, defining a sub-transcript, enables a linear global transcript by forking off the individual ones, yet seems unnecessary regarding IETF drafts. While I do believe in ensuring IETF compliance in apps, even when the larger protocol evolves, there are still work-arounds regarding `H(B, m, l)`, which is my recommendation. 

Also, to be clear, my main frustration wasn't regarding the hash clones, which alone happen regardless, yet the ambiguity around transcript continuation for protocols expecting transcripts to have a higher level of guarantees. I believe the solution there is simply to transcript `B, m`, do the `rho`s, and then where FROST discards a larger protocol can append `b"FROST_rho"`. As a byte string exceeding two bytes, it removes any potential of conflict and maintains IETF compatibility, while guaranteeing transcript behavior (not that I'm suggesting it for inclusion in the IETF standard, just noting possibilities for safe usage as a component).

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @kayabaNerve I'm not sure I understand your concern here. The transcript for computing rho is something signers must agree on, but isn't something that any higher level protocol built on FROST would use (or extend). Am I missing something? Do you have a specific use case in mind? (Also, separately, I'm not following your `H(B, m, l)` notation here. What are `B` and `l`?)

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
Sorry, that was the notation from the paper. It used B for the serialized commitments and l for the signer index.

Regarding the transcript, I currently have a setup extending FROST for usage in ring signatures. This means the signature as a whole has much more data which must be included as part of the binding factor, as it's not part of the message. It *needs* to have an extended transcript format accordingly.

I also have another design which preps a transcript as such, does one FROST signature, and then the next in a series. Accordingly, the transcript used for `rho` is largely preferred to be sequentially continued to guarantee a lack of conflict with any future challenges. While the next FROST round re-appends commitments/message, preventing FROST from triggering these conflicts, it's commentary on component safety whose security isn't reliant on external factors, without edge cases.

Regardless, I already commented above on successfully managing this, and am happy to withdraw my commentary on FROST's safety as a component for the IETF spec, which considers it an independent piece.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> Regarding the transcript, I currently have a setup extending FROST for usage in ring signatures. This means the signature as a whole has much more data which must be included as part of the binding factor, as it's not part of the message. It needs to have an extended transcript format accordingly.

This isn't a use case that's been considered yet, but it seems valid at face value. Can you point to an implementation or any documentation?

> Regardless, I already commented above on successfully managing this, and am happy to withdraw my commentary on FROST's safety as a component for the IETF spec, which considers it an independent piece.

This seems like a pretty unfair characterization of what's happening here. Safety is definitely _not_ something independent of the specification of FROST, or any IETF/IRTF work for that matter. 

What specifically about the existing proposal is unsafe, and why?

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
https://github.com/serai-dex/serai/blob/develop/coins/monero/src/ringct/clsag/multisig.rs for a reference, which I'm happy to share. The modular-frost library also defines/handles the Algorithm trait/handling as a whole.

Sorry. I definitely didn't mean to be unfair. My comment was that the IETF specification had this scheme available, which is the most efficient and more direct scheme, and I support it accordingly. It doesn't play well with certain extended schemes, who I'd argue the security of is their own responsibility. With a forked transcript, if the original transcript is the one continued with, requesting a challenge yet again may return a previously used challenge (where the previously used challenge would've been the binding factor). It's a minor nitpick, especially since a binding factor reused as a challenge doesn't break security necessarily.

While I do believe FROST should play nice where possible, which is why I made my comments on the implications of this, as I did believe they'd be listened to and feel like they were (truly not trying to be unfair), all of the schemes I suggested above have drawbacks. Accordingly, I noted a practical comment for implementations supporting long-lived transcripts, moving the responsibility to their realm, which solves this 'issue' without cluttering or degrading the specification.

I solely meant to acknowledge I considered this settled, and should've clarified "theoretical minor reduction with a complete lack of noted practical effect on out of scope usage in safety" :p I didn't drop this because I believe FROST, or its contributors, is/are being insecure. I dropped it because this isn't a security I'd like to advocate to make in scope, largely given its triviality.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @kayabaNerve shall we open a separate issue to track transcript construction and its implications for protocols that embed FROST?

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body: I don't think it's necessary :) But thanks for being willing to reach out like that. I appreciate the support.

issues.title: Optimize the Ed25519 implementation
issues.author: kayabaNerve
issues.body:
Follow up to #215.

Over 1000 runs with dalek on release, I locally observe scalar multiplication taking 268ms. Since we use the prime-order subgroup of Ed25519, we must perform a scalar multiplication on each group element we receive. Alternatively, instead of requiring group elements be prime order when received, we can clear their torsion in just 6ms (~2% of the time).

The naive way to update FROST to this would be with the following definitions for Ed25519:

```md
  - SerializeElement: Implemented as specified in {{!RFC8032, Section 5.1.2}}.
  - DeserializeElement: Implemented as specified in {{!RFC8032, Section 5.1.3}}.
    Additionally, this function validates that the resulting element is not the group
    identity element and is in the prime-order subgroup. The latter check can
    be implemented by multiplying the resulting point by the order of the group and
    checking that the result is the identity element.
  - SerializeScalar: Implemented by outputting the little-endian 32-byte encoding of
    the Scalar value.
  - DeserializeScalar: Implemented by attempting to deserialize a Scalar from a 32-byte
    string. This function can fail if the input does not represent a Scalar between
    the value 0 and `G.Order() - 1`.
```

modified to

```md
  - SerializeElement: Implemented as specified in {{!RFC8032, Section 5.1.2}}, after first
    multiplying the element by the multiplicative inverse of the cofactor (8).
  - DeserializeElement: Implemented as specified in {{!RFC8032, Section 5.1.3}}.
    Additionally, this function multiplies the element by the cofactor (8) before validating
    that the resulting element is not the group identity element.
  - SerializeScalar: Implemented by outputting the little-endian 32-byte encoding of
    the Scalar value.
  - DeserializeScalar: Implemented by attempting to deserialize a Scalar from a 32-byte
    string, failing if the input does not represent a Scalar between the value 0 and
    `G.Order() - 1`.
```

Please note this as insufficient as it will not produce valid signatures. The signature produced must have its nonce multiplied by the cofactor/never inverted, yet I care about discussing this theory right now than presenting a fully complete patch.

Pros:
- During signing, each signer performs two inversions on their nonces (considered with a weight of 50), and then performs cofactor multiplications (efficient by being defined as three additions) for t signers (considered with a weight of 1). This produces a cost of `2(50) + 2(1)t`. The current scheme has a cost of `2(50)t` due to how checking for the presence of torsion is done.

Cons:
- Not RFC8032 compliant, yet potentially still suitably compliant as it's solely extending with pre/post-ops when FROST already requires a scalarmul.
- We also need another function for SerializeElement which doesn't perform the inverse multiplication to produce signatures.
- Additional complexity in general.

It may be further beneficial, instead of modifying Serialize/Deserialize, to make cofactor a native property of the FROST algorithm. This would be more expansive than Ed25519 alone and not require an additional function. It would, however, increase complexity and remove the simple statement a prime-order group is required.

cc @chris-wood, who helped review the above cited PR and merged it

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: We are happy to take a PR towards this optimization but it is not a priority for the draft editors at the moment.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
After #290, I'm tempted to submit a PR on this since it seems torsion is still an active point of discussion requiring work.

The optimal solution, in my opinion, is:
- Promotion of cofactor to a curve property
- SerializeElement being * inv cofactor, serialize
- DeserializeElement being deserialize, * cofactor, not identity
- The addition of SerializeSignatureElement for producing the final signature, compatible with RFC8032 and other existing schemes

@chelseakomlo said a PR on this work will be accepted and I'll try to have one by tomorrow. This will hopefully close out all discussions on torsion checking/clearing and provide the best overall performance, though yes, it's a larger change than I would've hoped to make.

Alternatively, torsion clears can be removed from the RFC as irrelevant, and torsion checks can be properly noted. The former are present, when they're unnecessary under a prime-order construction, and the latter do not seem to be (though that should be resolvable without too much trouble, as an alternative to my soon-to-be PR).

comments.author: conradoplg
comments.body: @kayabaNerve if you don't mind please wait while we discuss this (I don't want to risk wasting your time). I think the main reason we closed this is because we want to compatible with RFC 8032, and torsion-clearing won't be

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
... yes, it will be. I fully understand that requirement and have incorporated it into my work.

https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/commit/ad3309f5fc4198bda84c63d5b14dd1e4490c5ce1 for the commit editing the draft alone. The entire FROST process is done with SerializePrimeOrderElement and DeserializePrimeOrderElement. The produced signatures use SerializeElement however. This means the signatures are RFC 8032 compliant.

And sorry for not listening to you and coming back with the proposed edits. I only just saw your reply.

issues.title: Ed448 Sage PoC isn't RFC8032 compliant
issues.author: kayabaNerve
issues.body:
I misdiagnosed this issue originally, yet have re-opened it in a correct form.

The RFC8032 Python code for EdDSA has the following statement:
`print(Edwards448Point.stdbase().double().encode().hex())`
print
`ed8693eacdfbeada6ba0cdd1beb2bcbb98302a3a8365650db8c4d88a726de3b7d74d8835a0d76e03b0c2865020d659b38d04d74a63e905ae80`

The Sage PoC has:
`print(GroupEd448().serialize((GroupEd448().generator() + GroupEd448().generator())).hex())`
print
`3918e56df836e2325b4f0d5d2844d4b57294caa17ef9d8c0c15b8a7b22c30dc945d857042fc0b79c971b02dea5334b1627e5cdace47790d400`

Given the inclusion of Ed448 was predicated on RFC8032 compliance, this should be corrected.

I also note the PoC defines a Decaf448 impl, yet the draft doesn't define a spec for it. Is there a reason for that? Considering how little used Ed448 is, I don't feel a need to advocate for Decaf448 (which unfortunately wasn't used in RFC8032 for whatever reason), yet it was a point of interest. I've also now seen references to a newer Decaf448, along with a Ristretto for Ed448, so it's hard to endorse Decaf448 (or anything associated) until review of the variety of schemes occurs...

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body: The PoC uses the generator from the paper. The RFC process used a different generator (or at least, a different mapping of it which should've been used here). Will submit a PR correcting it.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
The Ed448 spec also has https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/issues/204 as an issue.

RFC8032: "interpret the 114-octet digest as a little-endian integer k."

FROST: "H2(m): Implemented by computing H(m), interpreting the lower 57 bytes as a little-endian integer, and reducing the resulting integer modulo L = 2^446 - 13818066809895115352007386748515426880336692474882178609894547503885."

I'll update #246 to fix this as well in a bit, after checking if any other discrepancies exist.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
The FROST H2 also simply says H(m) (where m is RAm), when it's actually:

`H(dom4(F, C) || R || A || PH(M), 114)`

F = 0 if we're supporting Ed448, not Ed448ph
C = ... actually, for once, we get to define a context string . No other ciphersuite naturally lets us like Ed448 does.
PH is additionally an identity function, or `SHAKE256(M, 64)` for Ed448ph.

So `H("SigEd448" || 0 || len(contextString) || contextString || m)` where len(contextString) < 256 would be a correct definition. I don't believe we need to further state that bound however since we're providing a sufficiently short context string, not stating how to define custom ciphersuites (though #243 proposes that, to some level. I believe the 8032-compliance bound would be on any ciphersuites specified in this draft however, not any anywhere, especially when those can never truly be stopped).

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body: ~~H1 and H3 also aren't using wide reduction nor a hash to field? I assume all of these should be moved to wide reduction since it's already required by 8032 for H2.~~ The PoC already uses wide reduction for all of these, just as #204 already did for Ed25519.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: @conradoplg will review this

issues.title: Include all randomness used for test vectors
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> I note, though, that the vectors could be slightly more complete by providing the random 32-byte values used in the calls to nonce_generate() (right now I can only take the provided hiding and binding nonces at face value, I cannot check that they were produced with the H3 hash function).

issues.title: Should ristretto255 DeserializeElement function reject the identity element?
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: From @pornin's review. For comparison, the Ed25519 suite _does_ reject the identity element:

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Yes, it should, as currently the draft does not consider identity elements for either the public key or commitment. I'll fix this up.

issues.title: Identifier allocation
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

>   - The allocation of identifiers to individual signers is not
    described. In practice, each signer is given an identifier at key
    generation time, and signers are supposed to reliably remember their
    identifier. If signers are dynamically told their identifiers are
    signature generation time, and could be lied to by the Coordinator,
    then bad things would probably happen.
>  - Section 5 does not state that each participant shall know their own
    identifier as well. Identifiers must be allocated during keygen,
    and the protocol assumes that such identifiers are unique and
    remembered.

Should the spec describe how signer identifiers are allocated, or punt entirely to key generation requirements? This may be related to #247. We should also require that signer identifiers are distinct (see related comment from @pornin below):

> Commitment list must be sorted by signer identifier, but it is not stated that all signer identifiers must be distinct.

issues.title: Add duplicate signer check
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

>   - All sets of participants assume that there is no duplicate (the same
    participant should appear only once in the set, and all participants
    should have distinct identifiers). There are no explicit checks of
    that property in the described functions, but there should probably
    be such a check somewhere. I suggest adding such checks for all
    values which are received by the involved parties; in particular by
    participants when receiving the group commitments: the participants
    should verify that the values are in the proper order (by increasing
    identifier values) and that there is no duplicate.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body:
This case is currently captured by #281, but the check is quite buried. 

Do we need a higher-level check as well, or will #281 suffice?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I think #281 resolves the comment and we can close this, but @pornin please reopen if you disagree!

issues.title: Clarify challenge length
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

>   - A point worth mentioning is that all signatures in this draft use a
    "challenge" of the same size as the scalar field, but this is not an
    actual requirement of Schnorr signatures. In fact it is just a sort
    of tradition, established for no good reasons. In his original
    paper, Schnorr explained that for n-bit security and a 2n-bit group,
    the challenge only needs to have length n bits, not 2n bits. This
    may lead to a signature encoding that contains (c,z) instead of
    (R,z). The advantage of doing so is that it makes signatures shorter
    (e.g. 48 bytes instead of 64); it also speeds up signature
    verification. As far as I can tell, this would be compatible with
    the FROST scheme.
    I (very recently!) defined such a scheme for double-odd curves, see
    https://eprint.iacr.org/2022/1052 (section 7) for details and some
    analysis. In particular there is a paper by Neven, Smart and
    Warinshi that analyzes the security of doing so in great details:
       https://www.esat.kuleuven.be/cosic/publications/article-1167.pdf

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: This is a good point; this seems difficult to specify cleanly over different ciphersuites. A PR from @pornin here would be helpful.

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
Wouldn't it be best done as, whoever deploys this, defining a new ciphersuite whose hash output is just 16-bytes? While the IETF draft will produce a signature formatted R, s, it's possible to convert that as c, s without issue IIRC. The main note I'd have about an effective reversion to classical Schnorr signature is how FROST follows the EdDSA standard of r + cx yet classical signatures were r - cx. Accordingly, FROST isn't usable there, unless a FROST specific hash function returning the Scalar negative is supplied (or custom share algorithms in general are).

The only issue I would see if if FROST assumed hash outputs >= the scalar field size, yet the wire format spec was removed and I don't believe the spec does have that assumption.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Agreed. I think this could best be dealt with as a new ciphersuite. @chelseakomlo, I suggest we close this without change.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: @chris-wood Sounds good. @pornin see discussion above regarding the decision to close without change.

issues.title: Polynomial interpolation should check for duplicate points
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> 4.2.3 Deriving the constant term of a polynomial

    "L.append(point.x)" -> This does not check for duplicates. In
    section 4.2.2, L was stated as "the set of x-coordinates", and sets
    do not have duplicate elements; this raises the question of what
    happens (and what should happen) when trying to insert twice the
    same value in a set. Also, the use of "append()" sort of hints as
    this set being, in fact, a list, hence a structure that can store
    the same value several times.

issues.title: Prime-Order group updates
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

> 3.1 Prime-Order Group

    THe text should state explicitly that: "It is assumed that
    group element addition, negation, and equality comparisons can be
    efficiently computed for arbitrary group elements."

    "a unique byte array buf" (in SerializeElement()): if the intent is
    that a given group element admits a single valid encoding as bytes,
    then this should be stated so. Similarly, in DeserializeElement(),
    "a valid byte representation of an element" can be interpreted as a
    hint for the potential existence of several representations of the
    same element, which is at odds with the idea that the output of
    SerializeElement() is "unique"; maybe write it as "the unique valid
    byte representation of an element"?

issues.title: Explain key share and secret key relationship
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

>     The relationship between the key shares sk_i, and the aggregate
    secret key s, is not explained (normally, sk_i = f(Scalar(i)) for
    some implicit polynomial f of degree at most NUM_SIGNERS-1, with f
    being indistinguishable from a uniformly random polynomial, and s =
    f(0); when using a trusted dealer, the dealer does generate f
    randomly and sends f(Scalar(i)) to the participant i).

issues.title: Signature share verification failures
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin's review:

> 5.3 Signature Share Verification and Aggregation

    "Excluding one signer means that their nonce will not be included in
    the joint response z and consequently the output signature will not
    verify." -> Excluding a signer does not necessarily prevent
    computation of a correct signature, if the Coordinator deliberately
    selected more signers than necessary. E.g. if the threshold is 5 but
    the coordinator decided to involve 8 signers, then up to 3 signer
    shares may fail without preventing a correct signature from being
    computed. This corresponds to the first paragraph of section 5.2,
    where it is said that the the Coordinator chooses _at least_
    MIN_SIGNERS. Normally, the Coordinator may _a posteriori_ exclude
    some participants (removing their parts from the recomputed lists of
    commitments and binding factors).

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body:
... except then each share will be for a different nonce. Not to dismiss the work of https://eprint.iacr.org/2022/833.pdf, but this suggests a robust process and the reversion to FROST1 closed out the malleability discussed there. Is there something I'm missing which makes this review correct?

EDIT: This comment suggested the malleability identified by the cited work could lead to a robust process. That is not a suggestion I wanted to make as that can not be done securely, and could only be argued as insecurely robust if you know the party which would fail before they do (which is not a valid argument).

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: @kayabaNerve you are correct. We'll update the draft so this point is not missed in the future.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: @pornin - FROST is not robust, meaning that if any signer whose commitment was used to generate the group commitment `R` does not respond or issues an invalid response, the signing operation will fail for correctness reasons. Hence, in either of these cases, the coordinator MUST abort and re-run the protocol using fresh commitments. I added language to further clarify this; please let me know if you have any suggestions for making this point clearer.

issues.title: FROST(Ed25519, SHA-512) feedback
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> 6.1. FROST(Ed25519, SHA-512)

    It may be worth pointing out that when deserializing a scalar from
    bytes, there is no ignored bit. Scalars are always lower than 2^253
    (the subgroup order is slightly over 2^252) so the top three bits
    are always zero, and some existing implementations will gleefully
    _ignore_ these three bits, which contradicts the canonicality of
    the encoding.

    DeserializeElement(buf) is defined here with an extra check to
    reject the group identity upon deserializing. Nothing in the
    previous text checked that the public keys and commitment points
    should be non-identity (and, for that matter, randomly generated
    nonces can conceptually be zero). In practice, probability of such
    an occurrence is negligible when generating keys and signatures with
    FROST. However, it can matter for signature verification, where
    malicious input is possible, and it can be important that all
    verifiers agree on what is a valid key or signature.
    RFC 8032 allows scalars to be zero, and points to be the identity;
    this applies to public keys (A), commitments in signatures (R),
    private keys (s) and responses in signatures (S). If strict
    interoperability with RFC 8032 is sought, then the same rules should
    apply to FROST.

    "Nh" is defined to be equal to 64. This notation was not defined
    previously. I suppose this is meant to be the size of the output
    of H, in bytes.

    The (sub)group order is denoted "L", which maps to what RFC 8032
    does, but conflicts with the use of "L" as the set of signer
    identifiers (as scalars) earlier in the FROST draft.

issues.title: FROST(ristretto255, SHA-512) feedback
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> FROST(ristretto255, SHA-512)

    Same comment about scalar decoding as for Ed25519.

    Here, DeserializeElement() does NOT reject the identity (either as a
    public key or as a commitment). It is weird to explicitly reject it
    for Ed25519 and Ed448 (in contradiction with RFC 8032) and not
    reject it for ristretto255 (where there is no existing signature
    standard that should be adhered to for interoperability). I would
    have expected the opposite (accept the identity for Ed25519 and
    Ed448 because of interoperability issues, but reject it for
    ristretto255 because the identity is a really daft public key).

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: This should be addressed now.

issues.title: FROST(Ed448, SHAKE256) feedback
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> FROST(Ed448, SHAKE256)

    H2() is defined as: "H2(m): Implemented by computing H(m),
    interpreting the lower 57 bytes as a little-endian integer, and
    reducing the resulting integer modulo L". However, this is not
    compatible with RFC 8032, which, in section 5.2.6 (step 2),
    interprets the full 114-byte output as an integer and reduces it
    modulo L. Thus, "the lower 57 bytes" should here become "the
    114-byte hash output".
    (It is somewhat weird to use 114 bytes here, since 1. for the
    challenge part in a Schnorr signature, there is no actual need
    for complete uniformity; and 2. the subgroup order is very
    close to a power of 2, so even using only 56 bytes here would
    still yield a selection indistinguishable from uniformity. But
    RFC 8032 is defined to use 114 bytes, so interoperability
    dictates that FROST should use the same length.)

    See Ed25519 and ristretto255 about the identity point (again, it is
    allowed by RFC 8032 but explicitly rejected by the FROST draft).

comments.author: kayabaNerve
comments.body: This is resolved in https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-frost/pull/246 which also resolved other differences which I don't believe were mentioned by this review.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Agreed. Closed as having been fixed by #246.

issues.title: FROST(P-256, SHA-256) and FROST(secp256k1, SHA-256) feedback
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> FROST(P-256, SHA-256)

    SEC1 rules formally describe point encodings of various lengths.
    Specifically, for curve P-256 (or secp256k1), you can get the
    following lengths:

      - identity point: 1 byte
      - non-identity point, compressed format: 33 bytes
      - non-identity point, uncompressed or hybrid format: 65 bytes

    Since the FROST draft mandates a fixed serialization length in
    general, the text should specify that for this ciphersuite, points
    should always be encoded over exactly 33 bytes. This would have the
    side effects of rejected uncompressed/hybrid formats, and also the
    identity point (with SEC1 rules, no 33-byte encoding can possibly be
    decoded as the identity point).

    It might be noted that the compressed format was long rumoured to be
    covered by a Certicom patent, so that some libraries don't implement
    it. In the Internet/PKIX world (RFC 5480, section 2.2), uncompressed
    format is the rule, with compressed format being allowed to be
    supported but not mandatory (so nobody used the compressed format in
    their X.509 certificates, since that would fail to work with some
    implementations). It is in the nature of patent law that absolutely
    no guarantee whatsoever can be obtained about them, even after
    litigation and an explicit ruling, which did not happen; but the
    usual assertion is that such patents, if they existed at all, should
    have expired by now. Of course, using the uncompressed format makes
    keys and signatures substantially larger, so there are tangible
    benefits to sticking to the compressed format; but it should be
    understood that some existing libraries that implement P-256 might
    not be up to the task.

    H1, H2 and H3 are defined to use "hash_to_field from
    [HASH-TO-CURVE], Section 5.3 using L = 48, expand_message_xmd with
    SHA-256, DST = contextString || "rho", and prime modulus equal to
    Order()." This is a slightly incomplete description, because:

      - hash_to_field() is actually defined in section 5.2 of the
        hash-to-curve draft, not 5.3 (though it uses expand_message(),
        which calls expand_message_xmd(), which is in section 5.3.1).
      - hash_to_field() expects a total of 6 parameters and 2 inputs.
        Here, one hould understand that the target field is the
        scalar field (of order p, and extension degree 1); the number
        of bytes L (again an overload of the notation "L"!) is meant
        to be 48 (normally it is inferred from the target field size
        and a "security parameter" k), and exactly one field element
        is expected to be produced from each call to hash_to_field().

    Also, the hash-to-curve draft defines and uses hash_to_field() to
    produce elements in the base field of some elliptic curve, which is
    NOT the case here: in FROST, this is used to produce elements in the
    scalar field. This may be worth mentioning explicitly (i.e. the
    hash_to_field() implementation of a hash_to_curve() function for
    P-256 cannot be reused unchanged, it is not the same target field).

issues.title: Tidy up references
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> 9.1. Normative References

    [x9.62] designates ANSI X9.62-1998, but this is not the latest
    version of that standard. There is ANS X9.62-2005 (for that one it's
    "ANS" and not "ANSI", I don't know why), and more recently ANSI
    X9.142-2020 was published, which states that "This document cancels
    and replaces the previous edition of the Standard, which was ANS
    X9.62-2005." Thus, the actual reference should theoretically be:

   [x9.142]   ANSI, "Public Key Cryptography for the Financial Services
              Industry - The Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm
              (ECDSA)", ANSI X9.142-2020, September 2020.

    Note that none of these standards is free! The latest more-or-less
    freely available version is a "working draft" of X9.62-1998. I have
    a (legitimately bought) copy of X9.62-2005; I do not have
    X9.142-2020 (though the preview on the ANSI webstore covers enough
    to see the assertion that it replaces X9.62-2005). I can confirm
    that X9.62-2005 agrees with the X9.62-1998 draft in all the
    essentials (in particular encoding formats) and I have not heard of
    X9.142-2020 having changed things substantially in that respect (but
    they might not have told me if it did!).

    It is of course always a bother to reference non-free standards.
    Pointing to an old, twice-deprecated-and-replaced standard is not
    comfortable, but neither is pointing to a new standard that we could
    not actually look at. I don't have a good answer here, but I think
    that switching from X9.62-1998 to X9.62-2005 would be a gain,
    leading to:

   [x9.62]    ANSI, "Public Key Cryptography for the Financial Services
              Industry: the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm
              (ECDSA)", ANS X9.62-2005, November 2005.

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Closed by #272

issues.title: Note verifier optimization
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> Appendix B. Schnorr Signature Verification for Prime-Order Groups

    I am not sure whether this is worth mentioning, but the signature
    verification process can be sped up with the Antipa et al.
    optimization, coupled with the lattice basis reduction algorithm
    from https://eprint.iacr.org/2020/454 (yes, I am aware that I am
    quoting myself here). On Ed25519, this reduces verification cost
    from 129k cycles to 114k, on a recent x86 system, and the gain
    is greater for slower curves (e.g. P-256 or Ed448).

comments.author: chelseakomlo
comments.body: Closing as the algorithm to implement is not well-defined in the cited papers.

issues.title: Input message validation fixes
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> 7.4 Input Message Validation

    "As another example, use of threshold signatures in TLS [TLS] to
    produce signatures of transcript hashes might require that signers
    check that the input message is a valid TLS transcript from which
    the corresponding transcript hash can be derived."
    -> This raises the issue of pre-hashing. EdDSA, as defined in RFC
    8032, has several modes, depending on whether the message to sign m
    is used directly in the signature process, or first hashed, the hash
    value being then used in the process. In a TLS-1.2 implementation,
    the raw concatenation of the handshake messages is used, but TLS-1.2
    only supports ECDSA, not EdDSA, and in ECDSA pre-hashing is used
    systematically. In TLS-1.3, the input to the signature algorithm is
    a byte sequence that is the concatenation of a domain-separation
    string and the transcript hash, i.e. if EdDSA is used then "pure"
    mode is used (no pre-hashing), except that the non-pre-hashed
    message is, in fact, a hash output.

    A lot of confusion (hence interoperability issues) can raise from
    this pre-hashing concept. In general, pre-hashing is useful for
    implementations since it avoids buffering potentially large inputs
    (with "pure" EdDSA, you cannot start hashing the data until you know
    which public/private key pair you are going to use, and that would
    be quite inconvenient in a TLS-1.2 context, especially for small
    embedded systems, since the need for a client signature and the
    relevant key are discovered quite late in the handshake), which is
    why TLS-1.3 uses the "transcript-hash". A similar situation happens
    for instance in CMS (aka "PKCS#7", the generic format which powers
    S/MIME and other similar things), in which a signature on a message
    is really a signature on a set of "signed attributes", one of which
    containing a hash value over the actual content bytes. In other
    words, even if the signature mechanism itself does not include some
    pre-hashing, protocols will go to great lengths to put it back in
    some way.

    EdDSA was defined with a "pure" mode because it was published right
    in the middle of the Great Hash Function Scare, that was initiated
    when MD5 got broken, and led to the assumption (which turned out not
    to be true) that SHA-2 functions were soon going to fall;
    non-pre-hashed signatures are resilient to collision attacks, in a
    way that pre-hashed signatures are not. From a conceptual security
    point of view, "pure" mode is a gain. From a practical point of
    view, though, pure mode is a hassle. This has led RFC 8032 to try to
    define both "pure" and "pre-hashed" modes, which complicates APIs.
    From my own cursory experience, nobody uses RFC 8032 pre-hashed
    signatures, but many protocols actually use PureEdDSA over what
    really is a hash value, like what is done in TLS-1.3. It's all a bit
    messy.

    My suggestions:

      - State explicitly in the text that FROST signatures do not use
        any pre-hashing by themselves, but of course protocols that use
        FROST signatures can totally do some pre-hashing and apply the
        FROST signatures on something which is already a hash value. In
        that case, the used hashing process shall employ a properly
        collision-resistant hash function with a security level
        commensurate with the security inherent to the group used in
        FROST.

      - In section 7.4 and the TLS example, alter the text to state
        something along the lines of: "As another example, use of
        threshold signatures in TLS to produce signatures of transcript
        hashes might require the signers receive the source handshake
        messages themselves, and recompute the transcript hash which is
        used as input message to the signature generation process, so
        that they can verify that they are signing a proper TLS
        transcript hash and not some other data."

issues.title: Random scalar generation clarifications
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From @pornin:

> D.1. Rejection Sampling

    It might be worth mentioning that a safe (constant-time)
    implementation of rejection sampling must take care not to leak
    extra information. A naive implementation will scan the source bytes
    in high-to-low order and exit the loop as soon as a source byte
    differs from the corresponding modulus byte, and that means a
    side-channel that leaks how many top source bytes are equal to the
    top modulus bytes (and that side-channel can be exploited in a key
    recovery attack with Bleichenbacher's other attack).

and

> D.2. Wide Reduction

    For some curves, where the target curve order is already quite close
    to a power of two, the number of bytes to generate can be safely
    reduced. This applies in particular to Ed25519, Ed448, ristretto255
    and secp256k1, for which producing just as many bytes as the curver
    order size would already be safe (and would make the reduction step
    quite simpler). However, in all generality, the recommendation of
    x1.5 size is fine.

issues.title: Clarify how the verifier() in appendix B is stricter than RFC8032
issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body:
> 1.  I clarified my thinking about interoperability with EdDSA, and the identity point. The gist of it is that the interoperability which is sought in FROST is that correct FROST signatures are accepted by standard Ed25519 / Ed448 verifiers, but it does not go the other way round: standard Ed25519 and Ed448 verifiers (as per RFC 8032) may accept some signatures that a FROST verifier would reject. In other words, the verifier in appendix B is stricter, since it will reject points not in the subgroup (for both public keys and commitment points) that an RFC 8032 verifier may accept; similarly, the appendix B verifier will reject the identity point (again, both as a public key and as a signature commitment point) that are deemed acceptable by RFC 8032. This is fine! But it should be said explicitly somewhere in the draft. In all generality, and especially for consensus-based applications, it matters to be precise about what signatures are accepted and what signatures are rejected.
It is still weird, though, that identity points are accepted in the Ristretto255 ciphersuite: whatever reasons required the explicit rejection of the identity in DeserializePoint() for the Ed25519/Ed448 ciphersuites should equally apply to the Ristretto255 ciphersuite. I think the identity points should be explicitly rejected in the Ristretto255 ciphersuite DeserializeElement() function.

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/crypto-panel/kEwszf9MDNmdgJDnuUFaIHmBYwc/

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I don't think we should do anything for this. The verifier in Appendix B is not meant to be used for suites compatible with RFC8032.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closing per the comment above.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @pornin please reopen if you disagree with this conclusion.

issues.title: Cite faster way to verify if in the prime order subgroup via Pornin
issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body:
> 1.  Speaking of checking that points are in the proper subgroup: section 6.1 suggests that it can be done by multiplying the point by the order of the subgroup. This is true, that method works; but it is quite expensive (in my tests, it costs about 80% of a generic point multiplication by a scalar). It turns out that one can do better with some point halving using some isogenies. I just pushed it to eprint: https://eprint.iacr.org/2022/1164
(And I also implemented it: https://github.com/pornin/crrl/blob/471e15e5df1532395b1226f3b54370f458992225/src/ed25519.rs#L570)
This might be worth a mention in the draft, maybe?

https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/crypto-panel/kEwszf9MDNmdgJDnuUFaIHmBYwc/

While all curves with a cofactor != 1 in the spec have Twisted Edwards forms, making this unnecessary within this scope, I believe it'd be good to be clear.

issues.title: Protocol participant names
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: The draft previously used "participant" and "signer" inconsistently and interchangeably, and #282 unified them around "signer." But @dconnolly points out that might be confusing, since they contribute a _share_ to the signature, and don't compute the entire signature themselves. What about "co-signer" as the name?

issues.title: Raise an error if `SerializeElement` tries to serialize the identity Element
issues.author: dconnolly
issues.body:
Once upon a time we contemplated allowing the identity Element to be serialized to in theory we could support ciphersuites like RedDSA that explicitly want all possible group Elements that can represent the full distribution including the Identity as verifying keys. This resulted in SerializeElement not rejecting identity Elements, but DeserializeElement does raise an error if the bytes do deserialize to the identity

Now that we explicitly enforce that Identifer's, a restricted set of Scalars, can never /MUST NOT ever equal zero, we're kind of covered in general, and re-randomized 'forks' of this document that support the identity element can be created that do not affect the security / imply that an identifier can ever be zero and its commitment ever be the identity
